results.name: Triangular array (and fractal sequence):  row n is the permutation of (1,2,...,n) obtained from the increasing ordering of fractional parts {r}, {2r}, ..., {nr}, where r= -tau = -(1+sqrt(5))/2.
comment: Every irrational number r generates a triangular array in the manner exemplified here.  Taken as a sequence, the numbers comprise a fractal sequence f which induces a second (rectangular) array whose n-th row gives the positions of n in f.  Denote these by Array1 and Array2.  As proved elsewhere, Array2 is an interspersion.  (Every row intersperses every other row except for initial terms.)  Taken as a sequence, Array2 is a permutation, Perm1, of the positive integers; let Perm2 denote its inverse permutation.
reference: C. Kimberling, Fractal sequences and interspersions, Ars Combinatoria 45 (1997), 157-168.
example: Fractional parts: {-r}=-0.61..;{-2r}=-0.23..;{-3r}=-0.85..;{-4r}=-0.47..; thus, row 4 is (3,1,4,2) because {-3r} < {-r} < {-4r} < {-2r}. [corrected by _Michel Dekking_, Nov 30 2020]
